―
Policies to Meet Global Economic Challenges Asia’s 
Perspective

members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Developing Asia led the world recovery from the 2008–2009 global financial crisis. Asia’s 
economic growth rebounded strongly and has remained robust since 2010. In contrast, the 
sluggish economic recovery and problems faced in advanced economies—earthquake-ravaged 
Japan, the fiscal conundrum in the United States, and the worsening eurozone sovereign debt 
crisis—have unsettled markets and increased uncertainty over the economic prognosis in the 
medium term. Moreover, on its current trajectory Asia's growth could result in Asia generating 
more than half of global output by 2050 and boosting current living standards in Asia six-fold.1 In 
short, as the economic focus shifts toward Asia, so too will global voice and influence. Asia must 
assume greater responsibility in helping to manage change in a new world economic order. To 
do this, and to sustain economic growth and development both globally and regionally, Asia 
needs to define, clarify, and substantiate its position on a multitude of issues on the international 
policy agenda.  
 
2.  This technical assistance (TA) will increase the capacity of Asia’s policy makers (and 
their constituents) to contribute to and participate constructively in international dialogue on the 
policies needed to meet global economic challenges. The TA will provide Asia’s policy makers 
and the public with expert analysis and proposals on critical issues challenging economies at 
the global, regional, and national level.2 These analyses and proposals, crafted from a regional 
perspective, will focus on issues pertaining specifically to the needs of Asian economies, while 
at the same time considering the region’s increasing links with the global economy. The TA will 
provide  inputs  to  forum  discussions  such  as  the  Group  of  Twenty  (G-20),  Association  of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN),3 ASEAN+3,4 East Asia Summit, and Asia-Pacific Economic 
Cooperation (APEC), as well as to country-level discussions in developing member countries of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB). It will also provide Asia with policy proposals for collective 
action,  thus  promoting regional  cooperation.  By  assembling  a  broad and  diverse group of 
experts steered by a prominent research institute, the TA will be able to foster intellectual 
dialogue and debate on policies to meet critical global economic challenges, and therefore 
better inform policy makers and the public. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Global economic challenges and opportunities are in a continuous state of flux, testing 
the global economy’s capacity to adapt to evolving risks and priorities. The recent financial crisis 
led to a major reassessment of the global economic and financial architecture, and calls for 
more sustainable and inclusive growth in the face of a changing natural environment have 
gathered momentum.6 This changing global landscape requires a synthesis of regional and 
global solutions. This TA will focus on three major critical issues: (i) global rebalancing and 
sustainable growth, (ii) regional cooperation in a global context, and (iii) green growth and 
sustainable development. With an emphasis on Asia, the TA will examine these issues in 
greater detail and prepare policy recommendations for discussion in regional and global policy 
forums. 
 
                                                
1 Kohli et al., eds. 2011. Asia 2050: Realizing the Asian Century. Manila: ADB. 
2 In this TA, Asia refers to ADB’s 48 regional members.  
3 ASEAN consists of Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Malaysia, 
Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Viet Nam. 
4 ASEAN+3 consists of the ASEAN countries plus the People’s Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea. 
5 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 1 August 2011. 
6 J. Sachs et al., eds. 2010. The Future Global Reserve System—an Asian Perspective. Manila: ADB; and ADB. 
2008. Technical Assistance for South Asia Forum on the Impact of Global Economic and Financial Crisis. Manila 
(TA 6508-REG, $800,000, approved on 12 December).

2  
4.  Global  structural  imbalances  in  trade  and  financial  flows—and  the  associated 
unprecedented accumulation of international reserves by developing countries (especially in 
Asia)—played an important role in the recent crisis. Two years after the global crisis, the 
recovery in advanced economies―still repairing balance sheets and deleveraging household 
debt―remains anemic, and could remain sluggish due to continuing fiscal and sovereign debt 
issues. In contrast, emerging economies, particularly in developing Asia, are seeing robust 
growth. With the current economic woes in advanced economies, however, an Asian growth 
paradigm that relies heavily on export demand is no longer viable. Rebalancing sources of 
growth from exports to domestic demand is therefore critical for Asia. Not only will rebalancing 
help insulate Asia from future external economic shocks, it will also help foster a stronger, more 
vibrant, and more resilient global economy. Indeed, this rebalancing has started, with economic 
growth relying more on developing Asia’s domestic and regional demand and less on demand 
from advanced economies. 
 
5.  Rebalancing for a stronger, more sustainable, and more balanced global economy will 
require  a  series  of  domestic  structural  reforms  that  promote  domestic  spending,  increase 
intraregional trade within Asia and trade with other emerging economies, and intensify regional 
and global policy coordination. The TA will focus on macroeconomic aspects of rebalancing and 
will attempt to resolve the following crucial questions: 
(i)  How will global rebalancing evolve after the global financial crisis?  
(ii)  How  will  Asian  economies  that  are  overly  reliant  on  exports  rebalance  their 
sources of growth?  
(iii)  How can regional cooperation stimulate intraregional trade and regional demand?  
(iv)  How can global cooperation—such as the G-20 Mutual Assessment Process—be 
further strengthened to ensure strong, sustainable, and balanced growth?  
(v)  How should automatic stabilizers be built into the global economy?  
(vi)  How can global economic governance and the international monetary system be 
reformed to help the global rebalancing process? 
 
6.  Since the 1997–1998 Asian financial crisis, ASEAN+3 has made significant progress in 
regional  cooperation  by  focusing  on  establishing  a  regional  liquidity  support  mechanism, 
developing regional bond markets, and reinforcing the economic review and policy dialogue 
process. Development of ASEAN+3 monetary and financial cooperation has contributed to 
economic  and  financial  stability  and  regional  integration.  With  Asia’s  growing  economic 
influence, the region should further increase economic integration and cooperation efforts. In the 
meantime, the global financial crisis has called for global solutions and cooperation. The post-
crisis  landscape  highlights  the  need  for  formal  collaboration  mechanisms  between  Asian 
economies and global institutions. To meet these challenges, collective regional and global 
action should be complementary and mutually reinforcing. Asia’s collaboration should not be at 
the cost of its openness with the rest of the world—it must adhere to its long-standing strategy 
of “open regionalism.” 
 
7.  With particular focus on regional trade and financial cooperation, the TA will examine 
areas  such  as  reinforcement  of  regional  and  global  financial  safety  nets,  financial  market 
development, macroeconomic and financial surveillance, market efficiency and transparency, 
and free trade agreements. Specifically, the TA will address the following questions:  
(i)  How can the Chiang Mai Initiative Multilateralization develop a crisis prevention 
function and cooperate with the International Monetary Fund, given the relative 
strengths and specialized roles of each?7  
(ii)  How and where does the region further deepen financial cooperation? 
                                                
7 The Chiang Mai Initiative Multilateralization is a multilateral currency swap contract that covers all ASEAN+3 
members. Its core functions are to (i) address balance of payment and short-term liquidity difficulties in the region, 
and (ii) supplement existing international financial arrangements. Its current size is $120 billion.

3
(iii)  What is the role of global institutions such as the International Monetary Fund in 
regional surveillance?  
(iv)  How can regional free trade agreements be further expanded and how do they 
relate to existing global arrangements?  
 
8.  In addition, general themes may need to be explored, such as how should regional and 
global financial and trade arrangements interact, and what are the main impediments to closer 
cooperation with global institutions. 
 
9.  Environmental damage and resource depletion from rapid growth are already impeding 
Asia’s development, and anticipated increased affluence will place tremendous pressure on 
finite natural resources. Moreover, with Asia home to more than half the world’s population, 
climate change has far-reaching implications. Asia needs to find regional and global solutions to 
sustain future development. Indeed, early and aggressive action is urgently needed—simulation 
analyses suggest Asian economies stand to suffer most from inaction (footnote 1). Asia’s future 
competitiveness will depend heavily on how efficiently it uses natural resources and moves 
toward a low-carbon future. Asia can better compete in a global economy where resource 
efficiency, clean energy, and low carbon are the ingredients of success and prosperity—the 
future of economic growth is low-carbon growth. 
 
10.  The economy, natural resource utilization, and climate change are interdependent. Only 
concerted action and an integrated policy vision can give Asia the lead as the 21st century 
moves forward. Green growth has great potential to provide a clear and focused agenda for 
action and policies to pursue economic growth while preventing environmental degradation, 
biodiversity loss, and unsustainable natural resource use. Asia must choose policies that are in 
its own best economic and environmental interest and which generate green returns to growth. 
However, the complexities and technicalities require a multidisciplinary approach, which will 
then offer a range of policy options. Further scope for regional cooperation in areas such as 
climate change financing; energy, food, and water security; efficiency; and conservation need to 
be explored. In addition, reinforcing the existing regulatory environment to strengthen private 
sector participation in climate change and clean technology financing must be considered. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA will enhance the contribution of Asia’s policy makers to global policy making by 
increasing  regional  stakeholders’  awareness  and  understanding  of  critical  economic  and 
development issues challenging the global economy, along with the impact of these issues on 
individual Asian economies. The primary outcome of the TA is to enhance policy discussions on 
critical issues challenging the economy at the global, regional, and national levels so as to 
sustain Asia’s economic growth and development. It will promote coordinated policy responses 
by forging national commitments to regional and global international declarations, and foster 
greater and more efficient policy dialogue and interaction, both globally and regionally. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The  TA  will  engage  a  prominent  international  research  institute  (steering  institute), 
together with ADB, to organize and supervise the high-level International Policy Advisory Group 
(IPAG).  The  “virtual”  group—supported  by  a  project  website—will  consist  of  internationally

4  
renowned  economic  and  financial  experts,  chaired  by  a  leading  international  economist.8 
Members will be selected from within and outside Asia to ensure that views on issues covered 
are balanced and well represented.  
 
13.  IPAG members will prepare background policy papers. Specific topics―to be identified 
jointly by ADB and the steering institute―will fall under a uniform theme (e.g., one of the three 
critical issues). The background papers will then provide the basis for the group report—a 
consolidated set of IPAG policy recommendations. The individual papers and the group report 
will be compiled and published each year as an IPAG annual report. 
 
14.  There will be five IPAG meetings over the duration of the TA, organized jointly by ADB 
and the steering institute. To ensure Asia’s stakeholder ownership in IPAG, meetings will also 
be held within the region to gather comments from Asian stakeholders. The first meeting will 
start IPAG activities and discuss its future work plan for subsequent meetings. Thereafter, IPAG 
will meet twice a year in the following 2 years of the TA, for a total of four meetings. The draft 
background policy papers will be discussed during the first meeting each year. The second 
meeting  will  finalize  these  papers  and  the  annual  report.  Other  prominent  economists, 
academicians, policy makers, and stakeholders in the global economic arena will be invited to 
offer feedback and ensure that a well-balanced and finely tuned set of proposals are crafted, 
and that these effectively represent the views of Asia. To achieve maximum impact, the second 
meeting should be held just prior to the annual G-20 summit. 
 
15.  The annual reports will be available through both electronic and printed media. These 
will be disseminated extensively within and outside Asia through internal channels and public 
forums, to publicize IPAG’s work to media and a wide range of stakeholders, and to solicit 
feedback. The reports will also be available on the internet, primarily through the IPAG website, 
which  will  contain  information  on  the  group’s  activities  and  publish  the  annual  reports, 
background papers, and other related downloadable materials. 
 
16.  With  numerous  ADB  studies  focusing  on  post-crisis  policy  challenges  for  Asia’s 
economies—as well as policy briefs to foster dialogue and better policy making—the TA will 
collaborate closely with other ADB departments (including the Asian Development Bank Institute) 
to  incorporate  lessons  learned  from  earlier  studies  and  coordinate  with  ongoing  work.9 
Partnerships with other research and/or regional institutions with special interests in any of the 
research focus areas of the TA will also be pursued.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,245,000 equivalent and will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund.10 The detailed cost breakdown and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA. Capitalizing on the success of the Office of 
Regional Economic Integration’s (OREI’s) technical assistance for global reserve system reform, 
which aimed to enrich the current debate on the issue and empower Asia’s policy makers and 
the  public  to  participate  more  constructively  in  the  global  dialogue  on  the  global  financial 
architecture, the TA will continue to engage the Earth Institute at Columbia University as the 
steering institute.11 The Earth Institute is an internationally renowned research institute that 
draws  on  Columbia  University’s  scientific  rigor  and  academic  leadership  to  create  an 
interdisciplinary  community  dedicated  to  cutting-edge  research.  Furthermore,  the  Earth 
Institute’s tasks under the proposed TA are a natural continuation of the steering activities of the 
institute in earlier TA, in which it was engaged to organize a group of high-level experts and to 
provide specialized technical capacity and guidance to the final TA report. To maintain this 
continuity, and also due to the relatively small amount allocated for the steering institute’s 
services in this TA, the Earth Institute will be engaged through the single source selection 
procedure. In accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time), experts and consultants engaged for the TA shall come from ADB member 
countries. 
 
19.  The Earth Institute will be asked to submit a biodata technical proposal, which will form 
the basis for negotiation of a contract with the institute. The team to be provided by the Earth 
Institute will consist of (i) a lead economist and chair of IPAG, and (ii) a project coordinator. The 
Earth Institute will be responsible for arranging and paying all travel expenses and remuneration 
for  this  team  within  a  total  engagement  period  of  5  person-months  for  the  international 
consultant and 26 person-months for the national consultants, and other relevant costs. 
 
20.  OREI will be responsible for project implementation from September 2011 to March 
2014 and will involve the Earth Institute (with an estimated 31.0 person-months of consulting 
services), 12 international consultants (with an estimated 34.7 person-months of consulting 
services), and 4 national consultants (with 44.9 person-months of consulting services) to assist 
in TA implementation. Resource persons for workshops and seminars will also be engaged for 
approximately 2.3 person-months. OREI will establish a project administration team comprising 
two international staff and two local staff dedicated to administering consultant contracts and the 
arrangement of resource persons. The team will be appointed on a permanent basis for the 31-
month project period. 
  
21.  The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. Individual consultants 
will  be  hired  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). All 
procurement will be carried out in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,245,000 on a grant basis 
for Policies to Meet Global Economic Challenges―Asia’s Perspective, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Steering Institute: Earth Institute 
1.  The chair and project coordinator of the International Policy Advisory Group (IPAG) will 
be engaged as the steering institute. The steering institute will report to the assigned Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) staff and will coordinate with the rest of the IPAG in the preparation of 
the required outputs.  
 
1.  Lead  Economist  and  Chair  of  International  Policy  Advisory  Group 
(international, 1 consultant, 5 person-months) 
2.  The  consultant  will  be  an  internationally  renowned  economist  with  an  established 
reputation and well-known expertise in international and development economics and relevant 
professional experience in Asia. Acting jointly with the steering institute and ADB, the consultant 
will  
(i)  identify, jointly with ADB, members of IPAG; 
(ii)  guide members of IPAG, who will jointly be responsible for ensuring the analytical 
structure and economic relevance of ADB–IPAG annual reports produced;  
(iii)  coordinate and consolidate the work of IPAG; 
(iv)  provide direction for IPAG and identify topics to be covered by IPAG; 
(v)  provide expert advice to ADB and members of IPAG on critical issues during meetings; 
(vi)  discuss strategic aspects of the joint annual reports with members of IPAG, help ADB 
staff coordinate their work, and closely liaise with the economics editor to make sure 
that the joint annual reports are of high standard and quality; 
(vii)  incorporate comments from the meetings and draft the group reports; 
(viii)  together with IPAG members, finalize the annual reports, including the group reports 
and background papers, for publication; and 
(ix)  attend and facilitate sessions and make presentations during meetings to be organized 
under the technical assistance. 
 
2.  Project Coordinator (national, 1 consultant, 26 person-months)  
 
3.  The project coordinator, residing at the location where the steering institute is based, will 
be  mainly  responsible  for  the  activities  administered  by  the  steering  institute,  providing 
administrative support to the IPAG chair, and coordinating with the members of IPAG and ADB. 
The project coordinator will  
(i)  work closely with and assist IPAG and ADB; 
(ii)  assist in organizing meetings, jointly with ADB staff and the events coordinator; 
(iii)  prepare  and  guarantee  smooth  completion  of  the  required  reports,  including 
administrative reports, for timely submission to ADB; and 
(iv)  maintain proper communication with individuals involved in the research. 
 
B.  Individual Consultants 
 
1.  Executive Secretary of International Policy Advisory Group and Economist 
(international, 1 consultant, 6 person-months)  
 
4.  The  executive  secretary  will  be  the  primary  liaison  between  IPAG,  ADB  staff,  and 
resource persons. The consultant will be mainly responsible for ensuring the prompt delivery of 
the individual technical outputs of all IPAG members and the consistency of the annual group

Appendix 3  11 
reports.  The  consultant  will  preferably  be  a  renowned  macroeconomist  with  experience  in 
similar  assignments  involving  the  preparation  of  research  products  and  in  working  with 
international finance or research institutions. Under the supervision of the IPAG chair, the 
executive secretary will 
(i)  work closely with and assist IPAG and ADB; 
(ii)  provide assistance to the IPAG chair and ADB in managing the activities of IPAG; 
(iii)  liaise between IPAG and ADB; and 
(iv)  coordinate  and  supervise  the  generation  of  individual  papers  of  IPAG  members, 
production  of  annual  reports,  completion  of  group  reports,  and  dissemination  of 
research outputs of the technical assistance. 
 
2.  Economists  and  Members  of  International  Policy  Advisory  Group 
(international, 9 consultants, 22.5 person-months) 
5.  The consultants will be internationally renowned economists with established reputations, 
well-known expertise in international finance and macroeconomics, and relevant professional 
experience in Asia. Some of them may have expertise in the field of green growth. Acting jointly 
with the steering institute, IPAG executive secretary, and ADB, the consultants will  
(i)  write two background papers or policy proposals (one per year) depending on the topic 
identified by ADB and the steering institute; 
(ii)  provide advice for the identification of topics to be covered by IPAG; 
(iii)  liaise closely with IPAG chair, executive secretary, project coordinator of IPAG, and 
ADB; 
(iv)  present their papers during the meetings, and participate actively in the discussions; 
(v)  incorporate comments from the meetings into their individual submissions; 
(vi)  liaise closely with IPAG chair and executive secretary in drafting and finalizing the 
annual reports; 
(vii)  revise and finalize background papers for publication;  
(viii)  provide advice that will ensure the sound analytical structure and economic relevance 
of the studies included in the annual reports, including consistency for policy advice; 
and 
(ix)  participate in international conferences or forums to disseminate research outputs. 
 
3.  Economist and Editor (international, 1 consultant, 5 person-months)  
 
6.  The consultant will be a renowned economist with extensive experience in writing and 
editing economic reports and publications. The consultant will be engaged to ensure that the 
papers and annual reports are of high quality. Under the supervision of ADB staff and the IPAG 
chair, the consultant will 
(i)  review draft papers and suggest revisions to ensure the papers form consistent annual 
reports; and 
(ii)  assist the IPAG chair in integrating overall findings and in reflecting these in the 
overview section of each annual report.  
 
4.  Research Associate (national, 1 consultant, 30 person-months) 
7.  The research associate will assist ADB staff and international consultants with research 
work related to the papers and reports, gather data and information, maintain communication, 
and  prepare  technical  materials. The consultant  should  also  have  adequate  experience  in 
coordination work, preferably in similar assignments involving the conduct of workshops and 
economic publications. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the consultant will

12  Appendix 3 
(i)  work closely with and assist IPAG and ADB; 
(ii)  maintain  proper  communication  with  individuals  (e.g.,  consultants  and  resource 
persons) to ensure the timely delivery of papers; 
(iii)  establish and maintain databases and contribute to preparation of technical inputs 
required for the research; 
(iv)  provide  technical  assistance  in  reviewing  the  background  papers  and  the  annual 
reports; 
(v)  guarantee smooth completion of the group and annual reports;  
(vi)  work closely with the web designer in creating and maintaining the IPAG website; and  
(vii)  assist with logistics and organization of workshops and other activities.  
 
5.  Events Coordinator (national, 1 consultant, 6.9 person-months) 
8.  The events coordinator will assist ADB staff and the research associate in the overall 
administration and management of all the scheduled meetings. The coordinator should have 
adequate  experience  in  coordination  work,  preferably  in  similar  assignments  involving  the 
conduct of seminars and meetings. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the consultant will 
(i)  work closely with and assist IPAG and ADB; 
(ii)  maintain proper communication with individuals involved in the meetings; 
(iii)  liaise with suppliers for the meeting needs and logistics; and 
(iv)  organize the various meetings and seminars. 
 
6.  Copyeditor (international, 1 consultant, 1.2 person-months) 
 
9.  A copyeditor will be engaged to ensure that the edited individual background papers and 
group and annual reports adhere to ADB style and usage and conform to high publication 
standards. 
 
7.  Web Designer (national, 1 consultant, 5 person-months) 
 
10.  A web designer will be engaged to design the IPAG website and ensure that the site 
conforms to high standards of design, accessibility, and usability. 
 
8.  Typesetter (national, 1 consultant, 3 person-months) 
 
11.  A typesetter will be engaged to lay out the text, tables, and charts and convert the files 
into the required format for publication. The consultant should possess expertise in the layout of 
technical  publications,  and  preferably  have  extensive  experience  in  similar  assignments 
involving preparation of economic publications. 
 
9.  Resource  Persons  (national  and  international,  about  10  consultants, 
approximately 2.3 person-months) 
 
12.  Resource persons, with background as policy makers or experts, will be engaged to 
participate in the meetings to provide comments and feedback on the draft papers and reports.
